page.lettertext:
fol.142r
Belgia. 1591 14 May to my L. T
rea
s
Belgia: 1591: May
May it please yo
r
good L. to
e effect of my last w
ch
I
writ to yo
r
L.
e 5 of this moneth, there ys order taken that
wh
r
in these 2 daies the greatest
te of
e troupes, w
ch
are to
be employed in this sommer
s
vice shall meet together at
e
Vaert w
ch
is a fare by
Utrecht.
For w
ch
cause
Count Maurice
is gon
alredy toward
Utrecht, purposing p
nt
ly upon
e assembly of
e
forces, to march into
e field, There
was
are
w
th
him in company
the
L. Burgh
& his broth
r
S
r
John Burgh
, w
th
150 souldiers
w
ch
are spetially chosen out of every ensigne of
e
Briel
,
for
e bett
r
direction of
e affaires of
e warre, it is also
resolved
t
e
Councel of state
shall reside w
th
e Campe
but
e
g
na
l States
continew alwaies at
e
camp
Hage.
For my self I am purposed
alwaies
as occasions fall out
& as I finde moste behoofull for giving notice to her Hig
nes
of such actions as passe, to remain for
e moste at
e campe
& sometimes at
e Hage, for
e answere &
suit of such
causes & l
re
s as her
Ma
tye
may send.
S
r
Francis
Vere
being now at
Duisbourg
is appointed as this night
to surprise
e fort before
Zutphen,
w
ch
is supposed to bee but
weakly garded, failing of his purpose, hee hath order to
streighten all
e passages
t
lead to Zutphen &
Deventer
& th
r
after as they finde that those townes may be distressed
theyr siege shalbee planted before
e one or the other. Wee
are daily adv
r
tised of
e Enemyes preparations of boates,
bridges, & oth
r
needfull
vision, for
e passage of rivers
but we can not come to notice, what is ment to be exploited,
onely this daie we have Intelligence by a Burger of
Nieumeghen,
that
e Towne having often & greavously
complained
of
to
e
Prince of Parma
, that unles, they may
bee freed of that fort, w
ch
was built before
e Towne, the
last sommer by
e states, by w
ch
they finde themselves gretly
dammified, they shalbe forced ere be long to accord w
th
e states
fol.142v
Belgia: 1591: May.
the Duke th
r
upon hath p
r
mised to be shortly w
th
them
and
to accomplish theyr desire, w
ch
is all yet that wee
can
learne of any
te of his dessignes, There ys now
accorded by
e states a contribution of 10000
li
st
l
toward
e leave in
Germany,
& th
r
ys order also taken that yt
shalbe p
nt
ly paied. There are 2 of
e ships of
this contrey escaped out of
Spaine
by an adventure somuch
straunge w
ch
I thought not unworthy to be reported to yo
r
L
They were staied at
Calyz
in
Andaluzia
by co
m
ission from
e
King
& were freighted w
th
souldiers to watch in
e streightes
for certain English shippes, w
ch
were expected from
e Levant
one of them was of 100 last &
e oth
r
of 80, each of them
manned w
th
toward
30 mariners of this countrey. The
Maisters grieving to be [letted] of theyr cowrse & traffique,
agreed by secret compact, to ob
s
ve an opportunity, when
the souldiers were under hatches, & to shutt them fast
w
ch
they did very happely, & meeting by chaunce
at
e same time w
th
a shipp of
Breme
, forced her to take
all
e souldiers abord, w
ch
they caused to come forth from
under
e hatches by one & one, & were all sett aland by
the shipp of Breme. The oth
r
2 turned homeward
& are arrived in saffety at
Amsterdam
w
th
6 brasse
pieces of Artillery in eche shipp, &
e provision of
vittailes, powder & other necessary fourniture, w
ch
was
put in to
s
ve
e turne for w
ch
they were taken by
e King
And thus for want of oth
r
matt
r
I take my humble leave
Hage May 14 1591
